docs.lead_paragraph: SINCE the first forceps were invented in the 17th century, childbirth has been a ripe field for innovation. In this century, pregnant women have been helped -- or, some have argued, hindered -- by many new gadgets and procedures, ranging from epidurals to contraptions for exercising the pelvic muscles. Novatrix, a small company in Carlsbad, Calif., hopes that its ''labor assister'' will be the biggest thing in the hospital delivery room since the advent of the fetal heart monitor. The labor assister, for which Novatrix recently received its third patent, was initially the idea of Dr. Minying Gai, a Chinese obstetrician who trained at Columbia University and who now practices in Beijing.

headline.main: Patents; A 'labor assister' and other odds and ends aimed at making things better for new parents.

docs.abstract: Novatrix patents 'labor assister,' a plastic belt that straps around the top of a mother's belly and inflates in coordination with woman's contractions, exerting downward pressure on the fetus; says it reduces incidence of instrument-assisted delivery by 67 percent...Dr Kamran Ghodisian patents polyurethane membrane that is affixed to the belly midway through a pregnancy to reduce the likelihood or severity of stretch marks...Robert A Butnick patents crib for twins and triplets...Ashley Svopa patents 'expectant father system,' a kit containing items both useful and frivolous that is meant to accompany the father-to-be to the hospital (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Marisa Ottolenghi Nightingale and Todd Eric Edelman were married in Washington last evening by Rabbi Joseph Weinberg at the Washington Hebrew Congregation. The couple, both 31, graduated cum laude from Yale University.
docs.snippet: Marisa Ottolenghi Nightingale and Todd Eric Edelman were married in Washington last evening by Rabbi Joseph Weinberg at the Washington Hebrew Congregation.    The couple, both 31, graduated cum laude from Yale University.

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER finding high levels of the radioactive carcinogen strontium-90 in baby teeth collected on Long Island over the past three years, some organizations have appealed for more teeth to study the phenomenon more closely. The groups involved in the study, called the Tooth Fairy Project, said the presence of strontium-90 in the teeth of children born at similar times on Long Island, and particularly in Suffolk County, could be correlated to radioactive releases from nuclear plants in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
docs.abstract: Standing for Truth About Radiation of East Hampton and Radiation and Public Health Project of East Hampton and New York City, finding high levels of strontium-90 in baby teeth collected on Long Island over past three years, appeal for more teeth to study phenomenon; say presence of radioactive carcinogen could be correlated to radioactive releases from nuclear plants in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: He looked as cute as ever today, perched against the back wall of his feeding room at the National Zoo, munching on bamboo shoots. But Hsing-Hsing, the surviving giant panda of two that China gave the United States in 1972, is suffering from kidney failure, and zoo officials said at a news conference this afternoon that they could not predict how much longer he would live.

headline.main: Hsing-Hsing the Panda Is Severely Ill

docs.abstract: Hsing-Hsing, surviving giant panda of two that China gave US in 1972, is suffering from kidney failure, and officials at National Zoo in Washington, DC, say they cannot predict how much longer he will live; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline.main: When Building Up Leads to Breaking Down

docs.abstract: In this lesson, students examine where one develops his or her views about health and ways in which teen-agers exhibit these influences, focusing particularly on the rising trend of anabolic steroid use in teen-age girls. Students then participate in either developing and analyzing a survey of the student body regarding health and views of fitness or researching and designing an informational pamphlet containing information regarding steroid use and its dangerous effects, both which will be distributed to the student body.
